JUSTWORD	0005	1785	3022	1828	3040	no,
CENTERED	0001	407	82	1542	112	Costello, Donald P. and Catherine Henley (1971) <i>Methods for Obtaining and Handling </i>
CENTERED	0001	404	117	1531	147	<i>Marine Eggs and Embryos. </i>Woods Hole, MA: Marine Biological Laboratory, 247 pp. 
CENTERED	0001	846	281	1124	316	<b>BRYOZQA "' </b>
CENTERED	0001	856	367	1119	408	<b>(ENTOPROCTA) </b>
CENTERED	0001	856	420	1119	451	<i>Barentsza lava </i>
FOLLOWED	0001	304	1295	1738	1339	<i>A. Care of Adults: </i>The animals are hardy and easy to keep in the laboratory 
FOLLOWED	0001	304	1386	1739	1432	<i>B. Proczzrizzg Embryos: </i>Embryos and larvae are found within the calyx of the 
FOLLOWED	0001	309	2004	594	2036	<i>Butt., </i>94: 128 â€” 142. 
CENTERED	0001	973	2359	1007	2384	48 
CENTERED	0001	1061	2691	1305	2726	<b>BRYOZQA </b>
CENTERED	0001	1050	2778	1311	2819	<b>(ENTOPROCTA)</b>
CENTERED	0001	882	2839	1472	2881	<i>Pedzcellina cerzzzta (P. ectzinata)</i>
CENTERED	0001	434	2885	779	2918	<b>LIVING MATERIAL: </b>
CENTERED	0001	430	3086	1346	3128	is sometimes hermaphroditic, sometimes dioecious. 
CENTERED	0001	431	3165	777	3197	BREEDING <b>SEASON: </b>
CENTERED	0001	429	3272	1230	3315	probably occurs during the summer months. 
CENTERED	0001	429	3351	1146	3387	<b>PROCURING AND HANDLING MATERIAL:</b>
FOLLOWED	0002	490	21	1924	69	A. <i>Care of Adults: </i>The animals are moderately hardy in the laboratory, if they 
CENTERED	0002	427	67	1079	110	are supplied with running sea water. 
FOLLOWED	0002	489	114	1923	161	<i>B. Methods of Observation. </i>Cleaving eggs and young larvae can be dissected 
CENTERED	0002	423	437	871	480	larvae should be present. 
FOLLOWED	0002	483	577	1916	625	A. <i>The Ovum.' </i>The ripe eggs measure 40 by 50 by 60 microns, the shortest
CENTERED	0002	418	623	904	665	axis being apico-vestibular.
FOLLOWED	0002	480	670	1915	717	<i>B. Fert~lizatiort </i>artd <i>Cleavage: </i>There is some disagreement as to whether the
CENTERED	0002	410	1177	707	1218	the 90-cell stage.
FOLLOWED	0002	474	1223	1907	1274	C. <i>Later Stages of Developuserttt </i>Following gastrulation, there is an apical-oral
CENTERED	0002	1142	1387	1179	1414	49
CENTERED	0002	328	1511	1820	1556	the larva is set free. Shortly after this organ is formed, the stomodeum and procto-
CENTERED	0002	329	1557	1822	1604	deum invaginate on the oral surface, and the pre-oral or dorsal organ appears as 
CENTERED	0002	329	1599	1813	1650	an invagination on the anterior side of the larva above the mou th. At this time 
CENTERED	0002	329	1645	1824	1696	the egg shell vanishes and the larva is freed. When released, the larva swims with 
CENTERED	0002	330	1691	1824	1740	the aid of an oral ring of strong cilia, the corona. The digestive tract is complete 
CENTERED	0002	330	1739	1826	1788	and feeding occurs. Shortly after release, a well-marked invagination appears 
CENTERED	0002	332	1783	1826	1826	between the mouth and anus. This is the vestibule or atrium; it is bordered y 
CENTERED	0002	332	1828	1827	1873	the corona. Both the mouth and the anus are borne on long projections called 
CENTERED	0002	333	1967	1828	2018	face, and undergo a complicated metamorphosis which involves a degeneration of 
CENTERED	0002	334	2014	1828	2066	the apical plate and dorsal organ, and a complete upward rotation of the entire 
CENTERED	0002	335	2061	1828	2112	larval body. For further details concermng the larvae and metamorphosis, see 
CENTERED	0002	361	2230	1831	2275	oar, C. J., 1933. Dritter Cladus der Vermes Amera. Kamptozoa. Allgemeines iiber den

CENTERED	0002	1057	2771	1303	2805	<b>BRYQZOA </b>
CENTERED	0002	1052	2857	1307	2898	<b>(ECTOPROCTA) </b>
CENTERED	0002	889	2915	1467	2954	<i>Bugula ftabellata </i>and <i>B. turrita </i>
FOLLOWED	0002	494	3042	1926	3094	<i>Bugula flabellata </i>is found on the lower surfaces and edges of horizontal sub-
CENTERED	0002	429	3363	1387	3410	colonies can be recognized by the prominent ovicells. 
CENTERED	0002	428	3443	775	3477	<b>BREEDING SEASON: </b>
CENTERED	0002	426	3551	1476	3601	or second week of June until November I (Grave, 1930).
CENTERED	0003	428	23	1152	62	PROCIIRING AND HANDLING MATERIAL: 
FOLLOWED	0003	488	86	1878	141	A. <i>Care of Adults: </i>The animals should be provided with running sea water. 
FOLLOWED	0003	591	134	1921	190	<i>et </i>ods <i>of Observation: </i>Early stages of development can be obtained only 
CENTERED	0003	422	407	1754	456	not be released at dawn, but will be retained until th I ' d 
CENTERED	0003	420	637	836	677	development is desired. 
CENTERED	0003	421	715	867	751	NoRMAL DEVELoPMENT: 
CENTERED	0003	415	1099	790	1141	free-swimming larva. 
FOLLOWED	0003	477	1147	1911	1204	<i>B. Later Stages of Development: </i>The ciliated larvae of the two species of 
CENTERED	0003	1146	1270	1178	1297	51 
CENTERED	0003	333	1454	1826	1501	180 microns. Larvae of both species have a stiff circle of cilia surrounding a 
CENTERED	0003	329	1499	1825	1552	convex. apical organ on the pole which is carried foremost in swimming, The 
CENTERED	0003	329	1546	1824	1598	opposite pole is depressed and bears a central invagination called the internal sac. 
CENTERED	0003	330	1591	1825	1644	This depression extends up one side of the larva to the equator in the form of a 
CENTERED	0003	329	1638	1826	1690	glandular groove. At the apex of this groove is a tuft of long flagella (the vibratile 
CENTERED	0003	329	1683	1827	1737	plume). The lateral groove and the plume make up the so-called "pyriform 
CENTERED	0003	329	1731	1827	1781	organ." The larva of <i>B. turrita </i>has, in addition, four or six eyespots: two or 
CENTERED	0003	329	1775	1827	1820	four located on the anterior borders of the lateral groove, and two on the opposite 
CENTERED	0003	330	1820	1827	1872	side. When they are first released, the larvae are strongly attracted by light, but 
CENTERED	0003	330	1867	1827	1914	after two or three hours, they gradually become negatively phototropic. If they 
CENTERED	0003	331	2007	1827	2053	attachment is first made by the lateral groove; then the internal sac is suddenly 
CENTERED	0003	332	2053	1828	2094	everted and fastened to the substrate. About an hour after fixation, the larva 
CENTERED	0003	333	2098	1828	2149	begins to elongate, and in four to eight hours the body cavity is visible and the 
CENTERED	0003	332	2145	1826	2196	first polyp begins to form. The primary zoid is completely formed in 24 hours. 
CENTERED	0003	333	2191	1827	2237	From this time on, secondary individuals are produced rapidly by asexual budding, 
CENTERED	0003	331	2237	1828	2287	until a large colony is formed. Sexual maturity is attained about one month 
CENTERED	0003	334	2406	1827	2451	CoRREA, D., 1948. A embriologia de <i>Bugula Jlabellata. Uuiversidade de </i>Soo <i>Paulo Bol. d. </i>
